list.name: Changes
list.comment:
Expand language support with new expressions, statements, and control flow features
- Extended the `Expr` class hierarchy by adding new expression types: `Call`, `Get`, `Logical`, `Set`, `Super`, and `This`, enabling more complex language constructs. - Updated the `Visitor` interface to handle these new expression types. - Enhanced the `Stmt` class hierarchy by introducing new statement types: `Class`, `Function`, `If`, `Return`, and `While`, supporting advanced control flow and class-based structures. - Implemented corresponding `Visitor` interface methods for each new statement type. - Extended the `Interpreter` to evaluate the new expressions and statements, including logical operators and control flow logic. - Expanded the `Parser` to support logical operators (`AND`, `OR`) and control flow statements such as `if`, `while`, and `for` loops, refining assignment and block parsing. - These changes collectively enhance the language's ability to manage complex expressions, control flow, and class-based constructs, preparing the interpreter for more sophisticated language features.

task.summary:
Initial commit: Setup basic structure of the Lox interpreter.
- Created the `Lox` class in `lox/Lox.java`. - Implemented basic command-line interface with two modes: file execution and interactive prompt (REPL). - Added core methods: - `runFile(String path)` to read and execute a file. - `runPrompt()` for interactive execution. - `run(String source)` to scan and print tokens. - Introduced basic error handling with `error(int line, String message)` and `report(int line, String where, String message)`. - Added `hadError` flag to manage error state and ensure proper exit codes.

Add token type definitions and token structure.
- Created `TokenType.java` to define all possible types of tokens in the Lox language, including single-character tokens, multi-character tokens, literals, keywords, and EOF. - Added `Token.java` to encapsulate token data, including type, lexeme, literal value, and line number. - Implemented `toString()` method in `Token` class for easy representation of tokens during debugging and development.

Implement basic token scanning logic for single-character lexemes.
- Created `Scanner.java` to handle the tokenization process of the Lox source code. - Implemented the `scanTokens()` method to loop through the source code, identifying lexemes and generating corresponding tokens. - Added fields `start`, `current`, and `line` to track the scanner's position in the source code. - Introduced `isAtEnd()` helper method to check if the scanner has reached the end of the source. - Implemented `scanToken()` to handle single-character tokens such as parentheses, braces, commas, and operators. - Added `advance()` and `addToken()` helper methods for consuming characters and generating tokens. - Implemented basic lexical error handling by reporting unexpected characters during scanning.

Enhance scanner to handle multi-character operators, comments, and whitespace.
- Updated `scanToken()` method to support multi-character operators (`!=`, `==`, `<=`, `>=`). - Added support for single-line comments that start with `//`, ignoring characters until the end of the line. - Enhanced handling of whitespace and line breaks: space, carriage return, and tab characters are ignored, while newline characters increment the line count. - Introduced `match(char expected)` method to check for expected characters following the current one, used for detecting multi-character operators. - Added `peek()` method to look at the next character without consuming it, aiding in comment handling and future lexeme checks. - Improved error reporting for unexpected characters encountered during scanning.

Enhance Scanner to support string literals, numbers, and identifiers.
- Added a static `keywords` map to store reserved keywords and their corresponding token types. - Enhanced `scanToken()` to recognize string literals, numeric literals, and identifiers. - Implemented `string()` method to handle string literal tokens, including error reporting for unterminated strings. - Implemented `number()` method to tokenize numeric literals, supporting both integers and floating-point numbers. - Implemented `identifier()` method to handle identifiers and keywords, utilizing the `keywords` map for keyword recognition. - Added utility methods `isDigit()`, `isAlpha()`, and `isAlphaNumeric()` for character type checks. - Improved multi-character operator detection by fixing the match for `GREATER` token.

Implement Visitor pattern in Expr classes and update GenerateAst tool.
- Refactored `Expr` class hierarchy to support the Visitor pattern: - Added `Visitor<R>` interface within `Expr` with visit methods for each expression type: `Binary`, `Grouping`, `Literal`, and `Unary`. - Each expression class (`Binary`, `Grouping`, `Literal`, and `Unary`) now implements the `accept(Visitor<R> visitor)` method to handle visitor operations.
- Updated `GenerateAst` tool to automatically generate the `Visitor` interface and `accept` methods: - The tool now generates the `Visitor<R>` interface with visit methods for each expression type. - The `accept(Visitor<R> visitor)` method is added to each generated expression class, ensuring consistency with the Visitor pattern.
- Added missing semicolon in the generated import statement of `Expr.java` and included additional spacing for better code readability.

Implement AstPrinter for pretty-printing expressions.
- Created `AstPrinter` class implementing the `Expr.Visitor<String>` interface to traverse and print the abstract syntax tree (AST) in a readable format. - Added `print(Expr expr)` method to initiate the visitor pattern and return a string representation of the expression. - Implemented `visitBinaryExpr`, `visitGroupingExpr`, `visitLiteralExpr`, and `visitUnaryExpr` methods to handle printing of different expression types. - Developed `parenthesize(String name, Expr... exprs)` helper method to format expressions with parentheses, making the output clear and structured.
- Added a `main` method to demonstrate the `AstPrinter` by constructing a sample expression and printing its AST representation.
- The `AstPrinter` class provides a way to visualize the structure of expressions in the Lox language, aiding in debugging and understanding the interpreter's processing of code.

Add Parser to Lox interpreter for parsing expressions and integrate with AstPrinter.
- **Lox.java:** - Enhanced the `run(String source)` method to include parsing of tokens into an abstract syntax tree (AST) using the newly added `Parser` class. - Integrated `AstPrinter` to pretty-print the parsed expressions after they are successfully parsed. - Added a second `error(Token token, String message)` method for error handling that reports errors with specific tokens.
- **Parser.java:** - Implemented a `Parser` class that constructs an AST from a list of tokens. - Added methods for parsing different levels of expression precedence: - `expression()` handles the top level parsing. - `equality()`, `comparison()`, `term()`, `factor()`, and `unary()` handle different operator precedences. - `primary()` handles literals and grouping. - Implemented error handling with a `ParseError` exception to manage parsing errors gracefully. - Added `synchronize()` method to recover from errors by discarding tokens until a statement boundary is reached.
- **General:** - The Parser is now fully integrated with the Lox interpreter, enabling the interpretation of expressions according to the Lox language grammar. - The implementation includes basic error recovery to ensure the interpreter can continue processing after encountering errors.

Implement Interpreter for evaluating expressions in Lox.
- Added `Interpreter` class to evaluate expressions using the Visitor pattern: - Implemented `visitBinaryExpr` to handle binary operations such as arithmetic, comparison, and equality. - Supports numeric operations (`+`, `-`, `*`, `/`) and string concatenation with the `PLUS` operator. - Handles comparison operators (`>`, `>=`, `<`, `<=`) and equality checks (`==`, `!=`). - Implemented `visitGroupingExpr` to evaluate grouped expressions. - Implemented `visitLiteralExpr` to return literal values directly. - Implemented `visitUnaryExpr` to handle unary operations like negation and logical NOT.
- Added utility methods to support expression evaluation: - `isTruthy`: Determines the truthiness of an object according to Lox language rules. - `isEqual`: Compares two objects for equality, including handling of `null` values. - `evaluate`: Dispatches the expression to the appropriate visitor method for evaluation.
- The `Interpreter` class serves as the evaluation engine for the Lox interpreter, converting parsed expressions into executable results.

Add runtime error handling and integrate Interpreter with Lox
- Enforce numeric operands for arithmetic and comparison operators. - Handle invalid operand types for the `PLUS` operator. - Introduce `RuntimeError` for detailed error reporting. - Modify `Lox` to track and handle runtime errors during interpretation.

Extend Interpreter to support statement execution
- Implemented statement execution in the `Interpreter` class by adding support for `Stmt.Visitor<Void>`: - Added `interpret(List<Stmt> statements)` method to execute a list of statements. - Implemented `execute(Stmt statement)` to handle the execution of individual statements.
- Expanded the visitor methods to handle new statement types: - `visitExpressionStmt` evaluates an expression statement. - `visitPrintStmt` evaluates and prints the result of an expression.
- Retained existing functionality for evaluating expressions, including type checks and error handling for binary and unary expressions.
- This update enables the interpreter to process and execute statements, paving the way for more complex program execution.

Implement variable scoping with Environment class and extend Interpreter for variable declarations and assignments
- Added `Environment` class to handle variable scoping and lookup, supporting nested environments. - Updated `Interpreter` to manage an environment stack, enabling block scoping and variable resolution. - Enhanced `Interpreter` to support variable declarations, assignments, and retrieval through the `visitVarStmt`, `visitAssignExpr`, and `visitVariableExpr` methods. - Implemented block execution with proper environment management to ensure correct variable scoping.

Expand language support with new expressions, statements, and control flow features
- Extended the `Expr` class hierarchy by adding new expression types: `Call`, `Get`, `Logical`, `Set`, `Super`, and `This`, enabling more complex language constructs. - Updated the `Visitor` interface to handle these new expression types. - Enhanced the `Stmt` class hierarchy by introducing new statement types: `Class`, `Function`, `If`, `Return`, and `While`, supporting advanced control flow and class-based structures. - Implemented corresponding `Visitor` interface methods for each new statement type. - Extended the `Interpreter` to evaluate the new expressions and statements, including logical operators and control flow logic. - Expanded the `Parser` to support logical operators (`AND`, `OR`) and control flow statements such as `if`, `while`, and `for` loops, refining assignment and block parsing. - These changes collectively enhance the language's ability to manage complex expressions, control flow, and class-based constructs, preparing the interpreter for more sophisticated language features.

MESSAGE.value:
Initial commit: Setup basic structure of the Lox interpreter.
- Created the `Lox` class in `lox/Lox.java`. - Implemented basic command-line interface with two modes: file execution and interactive prompt (REPL). - Added core methods: - `runFile(String path)` to read and execute a file. - `runPrompt()` for interactive execution. - `run(String source)` to scan and print tokens. - Introduced basic error handling with `error(int line, String message)` and `report(int line, String where, String message)`. - Added `hadError` flag to manage error state and ensure proper exit codes.

Add token type definitions and token structure.
- Created `TokenType.java` to define all possible types of tokens in the Lox language, including single-character tokens, multi-character tokens, literals, keywords, and EOF. - Added `Token.java` to encapsulate token data, including type, lexeme, literal value, and line number. - Implemented `toString()` method in `Token` class for easy representation of tokens during debugging and development.

Implement basic token scanning logic for single-character lexemes.
- Created `Scanner.java` to handle the tokenization process of the Lox source code. - Implemented the `scanTokens()` method to loop through the source code, identifying lexemes and generating corresponding tokens. - Added fields `start`, `current`, and `line` to track the scanner's position in the source code. - Introduced `isAtEnd()` helper method to check if the scanner has reached the end of the source. - Implemented `scanToken()` to handle single-character tokens such as parentheses, braces, commas, and operators. - Added `advance()` and `addToken()` helper methods for consuming characters and generating tokens. - Implemented basic lexical error handling by reporting unexpected characters during scanning.

Enhance scanner to handle multi-character operators, comments, and whitespace.
- Updated `scanToken()` method to support multi-character operators (`!=`, `==`, `<=`, `>=`). - Added support for single-line comments that start with `//`, ignoring characters until the end of the line. - Enhanced handling of whitespace and line breaks: space, carriage return, and tab characters are ignored, while newline characters increment the line count. - Introduced `match(char expected)` method to check for expected characters following the current one, used for detecting multi-character operators. - Added `peek()` method to look at the next character without consuming it, aiding in comment handling and future lexeme checks. - Improved error reporting for unexpected characters encountered during scanning.

Enhance Scanner to support string literals, numbers, and identifiers.
- Added a static `keywords` map to store reserved keywords and their corresponding token types. - Enhanced `scanToken()` to recognize string literals, numeric literals, and identifiers. - Implemented `string()` method to handle string literal tokens, including error reporting for unterminated strings. - Implemented `number()` method to tokenize numeric literals, supporting both integers and floating-point numbers. - Implemented `identifier()` method to handle identifiers and keywords, utilizing the `keywords` map for keyword recognition. - Added utility methods `isDigit()`, `isAlpha()`, and `isAlphaNumeric()` for character type checks. - Improved multi-character operator detection by fixing the match for `GREATER` token.

Implement Visitor pattern in Expr classes and update GenerateAst tool.
- Refactored `Expr` class hierarchy to support the Visitor pattern: - Added `Visitor<R>` interface within `Expr` with visit methods for each expression type: `Binary`, `Grouping`, `Literal`, and `Unary`. - Each expression class (`Binary`, `Grouping`, `Literal`, and `Unary`) now implements the `accept(Visitor<R> visitor)` method to handle visitor operations.
- Updated `GenerateAst` tool to automatically generate the `Visitor` interface and `accept` methods: - The tool now generates the `Visitor<R>` interface with visit methods for each expression type. - The `accept(Visitor<R> visitor)` method is added to each generated expression class, ensuring consistency with the Visitor pattern.
- Added missing semicolon in the generated import statement of `Expr.java` and included additional spacing for better code readability.

Implement AstPrinter for pretty-printing expressions.
- Created `AstPrinter` class implementing the `Expr.Visitor<String>` interface to traverse and print the abstract syntax tree (AST) in a readable format. - Added `print(Expr expr)` method to initiate the visitor pattern and return a string representation of the expression. - Implemented `visitBinaryExpr`, `visitGroupingExpr`, `visitLiteralExpr`, and `visitUnaryExpr` methods to handle printing of different expression types. - Developed `parenthesize(String name, Expr... exprs)` helper method to format expressions with parentheses, making the output clear and structured.
- Added a `main` method to demonstrate the `AstPrinter` by constructing a sample expression and printing its AST representation.
- The `AstPrinter` class provides a way to visualize the structure of expressions in the Lox language, aiding in debugging and understanding the interpreter's processing of code.

Add Parser to Lox interpreter for parsing expressions and integrate with AstPrinter.
- **Lox.java:** - Enhanced the `run(String source)` method to include parsing of tokens into an abstract syntax tree (AST) using the newly added `Parser` class. - Integrated `AstPrinter` to pretty-print the parsed expressions after they are successfully parsed. - Added a second `error(Token token, String message)` method for error handling that reports errors with specific tokens.
- **Parser.java:** - Implemented a `Parser` class that constructs an AST from a list of tokens. - Added methods for parsing different levels of expression precedence: - `expression()` handles the top level parsing. - `equality()`, `comparison()`, `term()`, `factor()`, and `unary()` handle different operator precedences. - `primary()` handles literals and grouping. - Implemented error handling with a `ParseError` exception to manage parsing errors gracefully. - Added `synchronize()` method to recover from errors by discarding tokens until a statement boundary is reached.
- **General:** - The Parser is now fully integrated with the Lox interpreter, enabling the interpretation of expressions according to the Lox language grammar. - The implementation includes basic error recovery to ensure the interpreter can continue processing after encountering errors.

Implement Interpreter for evaluating expressions in Lox.
- Added `Interpreter` class to evaluate expressions using the Visitor pattern: - Implemented `visitBinaryExpr` to handle binary operations such as arithmetic, comparison, and equality. - Supports numeric operations (`+`, `-`, `*`, `/`) and string concatenation with the `PLUS` operator. - Handles comparison operators (`>`, `>=`, `<`, `<=`) and equality checks (`==`, `!=`). - Implemented `visitGroupingExpr` to evaluate grouped expressions. - Implemented `visitLiteralExpr` to return literal values directly. - Implemented `visitUnaryExpr` to handle unary operations like negation and logical NOT.
- Added utility methods to support expression evaluation: - `isTruthy`: Determines the truthiness of an object according to Lox language rules. - `isEqual`: Compares two objects for equality, including handling of `null` values. - `evaluate`: Dispatches the expression to the appropriate visitor method for evaluation.
- The `Interpreter` class serves as the evaluation engine for the Lox interpreter, converting parsed expressions into executable results.

Add runtime error handling and integrate Interpreter with Lox
- Enforce numeric operands for arithmetic and comparison operators. - Handle invalid operand types for the `PLUS` operator. - Introduce `RuntimeError` for detailed error reporting. - Modify `Lox` to track and handle runtime errors during interpretation.

Extend Interpreter to support statement execution
- Implemented statement execution in the `Interpreter` class by adding support for `Stmt.Visitor<Void>`: - Added `interpret(List<Stmt> statements)` method to execute a list of statements. - Implemented `execute(Stmt statement)` to handle the execution of individual statements.
- Expanded the visitor methods to handle new statement types: - `visitExpressionStmt` evaluates an expression statement. - `visitPrintStmt` evaluates and prints the result of an expression.
- Retained existing functionality for evaluating expressions, including type checks and error handling for binary and unary expressions.
- This update enables the interpreter to process and execute statements, paving the way for more complex program execution.

Implement variable scoping with Environment class and extend Interpreter for variable declarations and assignments
- Added `Environment` class to handle variable scoping and lookup, supporting nested environments. - Updated `Interpreter` to manage an environment stack, enabling block scoping and variable resolution. - Enhanced `Interpreter` to support variable declarations, assignments, and retrieval through the `visitVarStmt`, `visitAssignExpr`, and `visitVariableExpr` methods. - Implemented block execution with proper environment management to ensure correct variable scoping.

Expand language support with new expressions, statements, and control flow features
- Extended the `Expr` class hierarchy by adding new expression types: `Call`, `Get`, `Logical`, `Set`, `Super`, and `This`, enabling more complex language constructs. - Updated the `Visitor` interface to handle these new expression types. - Enhanced the `Stmt` class hierarchy by introducing new statement types: `Class`, `Function`, `If`, `Return`, and `While`, supporting advanced control flow and class-based structures. - Implemented corresponding `Visitor` interface methods for each new statement type. - Extended the `Interpreter` to evaluate the new expressions and statements, including logical operators and control flow logic. - Expanded the `Parser` to support logical operators (`AND`, `OR`) and control flow statements such as `if`, `while`, and `for` loops, refining assignment and block parsing. - These changes collectively enhance the language's ability to manage complex expressions, control flow, and class-based constructs, preparing the interpreter for more sophisticated language features.

option.name: LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE
option.value:
Expand language support with new expressions, statements, and control flow features
- Extended the `Expr` class hierarchy by adding new expression types: `Call`, `Get`, `Logical`, `Set`, `Super`, and `This`, enabling more complex language constructs. - Updated the `Visitor` interface to handle these new expression types. - Enhanced the `Stmt` class hierarchy by introducing new statement types: `Class`, `Function`, `If`, `Return`, and `While`, supporting advanced control flow and class-based structures. - Implemented corresponding `Visitor` interface methods for each new statement type. - Extended the `Interpreter` to evaluate the new expressions and statements, including logical operators and control flow logic. - Expanded the `Parser` to support logical operators (`AND`, `OR`) and control flow statements such as `if`, `while`, and `for` loops, refining assignment and block parsing. - These changes collectively enhance the language's ability to manage complex expressions, control flow, and class-based constructs, preparing the interpreter for more sophisticated language features.
